text: Family Member: it’s radium for sure? Doctor: Well, it’s radium as an option. You know, you guys might look at that and go um, I don’t know how I feel about it and after you talk to the radiation doctor who administers it, you know, some people might say oh, gosh, I just worried about it and I’d rather take chemo and that’s okay too. I’m just trying to make it so easy. I mean any and all of this is interchangeable. If you had just bone only, you could get chemo Patient: Okay. Doctor: but if you have not just bone you can’t get radium. So, radium is only good for one thing. You got bone you can get radium. Patient: Radium. Doctor: It can’t go anywhere else. So, if it’s anywhere else other than bone, no go on the radium. Taxotere, you know, chemo could be anywhere anytime, less picky. Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what? Doctor: Well, I think it’s controlling your local, you know. Patient: You think it made a difference? Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Oh, I think so. Yeah, those aren’t the problem cells. Those guys are dumb and dead. It’s the smarter ones that are like party. They may have not been even in the field of radiation. They may have already been floating around. So, just to also make sure we talk about the genetics stuff that you did because the biopsy didn’t really yield anything… Patient: Right, okay, that’s one of the things. Doctor: Yeah, right, it kind of all went south after that but we did check your blood. If you remember we sent a couple of tubes to a company called Guardian Health Patient: Yes.

text: Patient: I know. I know. Doctor: You feel it too, I’m sure. Patient: You get the PSA yet? Doctor: Not yet. But last time it was going down. Patient: It was one, one, yeah. Doctor: So it went from one point one. Yeah. Patient: How long does it take to see the CAT scan? Doctor: Oh, (sigh) Patient: Do I have to wait to see it? Doctor: No. I don’t think you need to. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Because, you know, everything’s going okay, and, uh- Patient: But if you see something, you’ll call me?

text: Patient: Okay. Okay. That works. Doctor: Questions? Family Member: I do, I think that, uh, one of the, I guess, questions that came up in my mind was the signs of the cancer development in the adrenal is it consistent that it would be prostate cancer or we just don’t even know Doctor: Yeah. I mean, the assumption is that it is prostate cancer. Why give him a second cancer? Uh. So, that’s the assumption. You know, the adrenal gland can have benign tumors in it. Okay? Um. You know, if prostate cancer went in there, that would be a possible reason why it would bleed. Um. Sometimes the adrenal gland just doesn’t get a good blood supply, and it does bleed. Or, if you’re under stress, or like today with your blood pressure shooting through the roof, but your scans were yesterday. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh. It’s pretty nonspecific. Your aspirin puts you at a higher risk for like various Doctor: -things, such as bleeding. Patient: Okay. Should I stop that? Doctor: No. I mean, my sense is you’ve been on it for some reason. I, but, we didn’t start it, right? Patient: Yeah, yeah. My, um, primary doctor did. Doctor: So, you know, that would be the person to check. Patient: Okay.

text: Healthcare Professional: Yeah, she doesn’t start I.V.’s. They have to have the I.V. tech start them. Doctor: for chemo. HCP Okay, I’m going to take these to K____. Patient: Uh you know if you’re uh if you’re driving around in a Mercedes, the least you could do is order a nice pen. (conversation in background) Doctor: Oh my turnover of pens is crazy. I never have fancy pens because I lose them. Patient: Your husband has a bunch of ‘em. They have their nice pens. Doctor: Oh my gosh; I didn’t know that. Family Member: He said he hides them. Doctor: I guess I don’t even. I didn’t even know that. Patient: Oh yeah, because I took one when I was down there and the guy (she gets after me for swiping people’s pens) Doctor: So mine are, you’re allowed to swipe. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, you can throw these away. (chuckles) Doctor: Well I use them so much; I mean I run out of ink and then I need to be able to toss and then move on to the next one.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - is we want to know whether your immune system is reacting to it. So our study isn’t whether you get the medicine or not. You get the medicine, regardless. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Our study is, will you allow me to get extra tubes of blood so I can measure these things that are affecting the immune system, so we get knowledge? That’s it. So there is no sugar. Family Member: Right. Doctor: There is no, you know, what we call placebo, or there is nothing that is not what is the treatment coming to you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Hum? Patient: Cancer’s like, uh, cancer is like a mucous. Doctor: Cancer is like a mucous? Patient: Huh. Doctor: Nah Family Member: I was always taught it’s an overgrowth of whatever.

text: Patient: Okay as far as working what do you mean by that? I mean is it something… Doctor: Working against – shrinking the cancer and helping – working against the… Family Member: Targeting drugs and genes (doc and fam talking at the same time.) Doctor: Targeting exactly the cancer that you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now there is another option, I know you’re completely reluctant to go on chemotherapy. You know there is obviously that would be the standard treatment that you know we would – if we advise that and if you decide you want that you could easily get it in lots and closer to home. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: But there is a newer hormonal therapy that also we can consider for you. Now that is sort of an earlier phase trial, so it’s a phase one trial. Okay. But the advantage is that we’ve already been through a number of the dosing levels. So typically a phase one trial is where you’re getting something very new that’s worked amazingly well in the lab that now you’re testing in people. So the first few dose levels really are trying to see what kind of side effects and what dose level really has… Patient: Sure. Doctor: But you’ll have some long days and things like that, you would have the hotel and mileage covered you know same as this study for that matter. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (clears throat) Doctor: So those things would be covered, but it is a matter of whether you’re willing to come back and forth.

text: Family Member: May be an option. Doctor: Because where we’ve been you know we’ve been talking about you know hormones is the base layer and then do we add chemotherapy on top of that? And then we talked to you about the clinical trial – Patient: Right. Doctor: - which is you know potentially adding a third drug on top of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So three punches versus two punches. Patient: Right. Doctor: Because everybody gets the hormones. Patient: Right. Doctor: And if we decide to do the chemotherapy it’s because we think it’s the right thing for you - Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you got to see most of the things you wanted to see? Patient: I think we did. Family Member: Yeah. We did. It was nice. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh, I just reviewed, again, all the scans from a month ago or so. So really what we see in you is all of the disease seems to be in the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you don’t have any really anything in lymph nodes, or liver, or lung, which is, you know, good and bad. Uh, the bad part of it is, you know, it’s hard to kind of get a good sense of how things work in the bone because the scans we do are, uh, mostly telling us new spots in the bone. But they, we can’t really measure things getting bigger or smaller. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Because it was- it ran from here all the way down to my ankle. Yeah. Doctor: So you know, being on the blood thinner for at least three months is sort of the minimum that we have to do. Patient: Right. Doctor: And we could potentially stop it. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then you know, your body if your leg swells up again, that may tell us that we need to really use it for life. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue that you run the risk is if it does show up and we'll catch it early or you're aware of it and it pops up in your lung. Patient: Yes, that’s not good. Doctor: That's something that can be associated with pain or sudden death. Patient: Right. That's right. My sister in law died of that. Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry.

text: Patient: Okay. Nah you can keep Dr. V____. Doctor: Well hopefully it will respond to the second one, the one that we use if people are resistant to this particular chemo that you’re on. I’ll give you information and the name and everything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know the paperwork that we usually do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The, it, the biggest side effect can be dropping of blood counts. So what you’re gonna have to do… Doctor: No. The best way to prevent it is we will give you a shot the second day, okay, the day after your chemo to um help prevent the blood counts from dropping. Patient: So this will be the last chemo? Doctor: Yes.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can tell you that the most important thing you can do is not gain weight. You do not need a special diet; you do not need special things. What is important is you don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you stay physically active. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all that’s important because I mean what is bad is if you get fat, fat is a pro-inflammatory environment and people who do get fat die quicker from cancer. All cancers. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, so, all these diets and things like that, all these special things people offer often at high prices, you know it’s great if you need that discipline, but the reality is don’t gain weight. Stay in shape; you’ll do better. Patient: So like worrying about my sugar intake and - Doctor: Don’t – in or out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
